introduction.p:
Consider a function that is piecewise-defined according to the formula
f(x) = \begin{cases}3(x+2)+2 \amp \text{ for }-3 \lt x \lt -2 \\ \frac{2}{3}(x+2)+1 \amp \text{ for }-2 \le x \lt 1 \\ 1 \amp \text{ for } x = 1 \\ 4-x \amp \text{ for } 1 \lt x \lt 2 \\ 2 \amp \text{ for }2 \lt x \end{cases}
Use the given formula to answer the following questions.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, compute f(a).

hint.p: Find the interval in which a lies and evaluate the function there.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, determine \displaystyle \lim_{x \to a^-} f(x).

hint.p: Remember that for \lim_{x \to a^-} f(x), we only consider values of x such that x \lt a. Find the right formula to use in the piecewise definition for f to fit the values you are considering.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, determine \displaystyle \lim_{x \to a} f(x). If the limit fails to exist, explain why by discussing the left- and right-hand limits at the relevant a-value.

hint.p: Use your work in (b) and compare left- and right-hand limits.

answer.p: \lim_{x \to -2} f(x) does not exist. The values of the limits as x \to a for a = -1, 0, 1, 2 are \frac{5}{3}, \frac{7}{3}, 3, 2.

solution.p: \lim_{x \to -2} f(x) does not exists because the left-hand limit is 2 while the right-hand limit is 1. All of the other requested limits exist, as left- and right-hand limits exist and are equal in each case. The respective values of the limits as x \to a for a = -1, 0, 1, 2 are \frac{5}{3}, \frac{7}{3}, 3, 2.

statement.p:
For which values of a is the following statement true?
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \ne f(a)

solution.p: For a = -2, a = 1, and a = 2, \lim_{x \to a} f(x) \ne f(a). At a = -2, the limit fails to exist, but f(-2) = 1. At a = 1, the limit is 3, but f(1)=1. At a = 2, the limit is 2, but f(2) is undefined.

statement.p: On the axes provided, sketch an accurate, labeled graph of y = f(x). Be sure to carefully use open circles (○) and filled circles (●) to represent key points on the graph, as dictated by the piecewise formula.

description.p: Graph the piecewise-defined function described here.

hint.p: Note that f is piecewise linear.
